Award.AwardTitle: 2nd International Conference on Microbiome Engineering; December 2-4, 2019; Boston, MA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this award is to support US-based students and postdoctoral associates and young professionals who will attend the 2nd International Conference on Microbiome Engineering to be held in Boston, in December 2019. The conference explores the importance and applications of microbiome engineering and will bring together leaders and experts from cutting edge fields of microbiome engineering to discuss progress and needs to develop research, technology, and innovation. The chairs and organizing committee of the 2nd International Conference on Microbiome Engineering are experts and leaders in their fields.
The field of pharmaceutical design and microbiome engineering is growing rapidly and needs collaboration between the professionals and young researchers in biomedical science and engineering. This conference will provide a venue for scientific presentations from a diverse group of researchers; encourage active participation by graduate and undergraduate researchers who represent the future of the field; bring scientists and engineers together to provide an atmosphere and venue to discuss their disciplines and approaches, motivate new research into barriers limiting the development of microbiome modeling and engineering and will have a particular focus on females and scientists from underrepresented groups. Peer reviewed conference proceedings will be published on the AIChE website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microbiomes consist of diverse microbial communities and exist in all types of ecosystems. Anomalies in microbiomes can disturb the balance of the ecosystem, resulting in diseases and disorders. Microbiome engineering attempts to mitigate these occurrences by modifying structures of the microbiota to restore ecological balance. Because of this, microbiome engineering has been instrumental in improving human health and agriculture productivity. It is in this framework that we designed the 2nd International Conference on Microbiome Engineering. The conference focused on understanding, harnessing and expanding the capabilities of microbiome engineering. The conference served to bring together engineers and scientists at the forefront of the field to discuss cutting edge solutions to problems in a variety of fields.

The conference featured four technical sessions: (1) Emerging technologies to manipulate and study microbiomes, (2) Computational modeling to predict and understand microbiomes, and (3) Engineering of organisms and communities for the environment and biotransformations, (4) Engineering therapeutic microbes for clinical applications. There was also a panel discussion regarding the changes in microbiome engineering spanning distinct areas of expertise. The panel was comprised of professionals from academia and industry.The conference featured a poster session, where students were able to present their work and receive feedback from professionals in the field.
